comments.commentBody: What man in his right mind would leave his own children with a man he KNEW to be a pedophile?

Of course Paterno could leave his own children with Sandusky. Sandusky isn't/wasn't stupid. Making sure Paterno could safely leave his kids with Sandusky simply helped condition (groom?) Paterno to think of him as harmless, and enabled Paterno to continue his "ignorace."
Good catch re: O. HENRY, Liz.  I won't make that mistake, should I ever have a reason to discuss him.

And, sadly, I get the impression - not only for your state but most states - that penalizing true "needers" of drugs and responsible users will soon be suffering much and greater "penalization."  Mostly because of our always-reliable federal government and its "expert" interpretations of information.  There is a rough road ahead for those who have true and proven need for pain-abating drugs.

One doctor's mistake in an operation has given me continual pain. No over-the-counter medication can cope with it. So now, doctors are penalized for prescribing it to me. What am I going to do? Commit suicide I guess. Thanks for nothing.

No one - except those suffering from pain due to a terminal illness - needs chronic high doses of narcotics. In my experience as a MD, patients use high doses of narcotics either to feed an addiction or to treat their psychiatric issues. The medical profession should never have started down this road.

Sadly, those who truly need medication and who are not abusing dosages are being penalized in my state of Washington. My physician agreed with me when I met with him recently that those who overuse prescription drugs are making it much harder for those patients who are being responsible. His fear is that with the state watching so carefully, his license will be revoked even if he is prescribing medication in moderate amounts to those who do not abuse.

Clearly there is a crisis of epidemic proportions with prescription drug use, but the law should be made clear that those who use medication properly, diligently and without abusing, should not be penalized by overzealousness. There are many in our nation who suffer daily with significant pain. There should be a case by case evaluation of each patient and that patient’s needs, as well as the patient's adherence to reasonable dosages of medication needed. In my state at least, this is not happening and many are being cut off of all medication, some without receiving any prior notice at all.

According to our Department of Health, doctors are not required to cut people off medication, that physicians do have the right to make determinations about what medications and dosages are appropriate. But as my long time doctor advised me, there is real fear among physicians now of losing their licenses despite the state’s assurance. There has to be a sane, humane solution for this so people are seen as individuals.
It's Friday night, and I just read the original challenge before reading the solution. My immediate thought was that it was some kind of strep complication. The strep symptoms are pretty classic.
You've been able to figure out what Mr. Trump's point is?  I'm astonished.

Totally disastrous route for Hillary to take. I've intended to vote for her, somewhat reluctantly, but if she starts pandering to that lot I really will stay home. And I'm adamant about not staying home - I vote. But that would be the last straw.  She'd lose a lot more votes than she'd gain - one of her real strengths is that we've persuaded ourselves that at least she'd keep the Repubs at bay. We'd dimly hoped that she might apply some of her savvy insider chops to that task even if she's not the candidate we'd choose.

Or maybe she'd put some of them to use.  Know that they see the horror they've produced they might just be able to put in a little bipartisan work.  I, too, would like to see some of that crowd pummeled to jelly, but we've got to start working  together again.

You wonder when you see something like this, how screwed up American politics has become:

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/07/us/politics/hillary-clinton-republican...

Ms. "I am remaking myself over again" Clinton plans to pander to independents and GOP voters who do not want to vote for Mr. Trump. We will come away with not knowing where either of these people stand; it the GOP debates were any indication. Honestly, Ms. Clinton trying to say she has GOP leanings, with liberal leanings, with middle of the road leanings? Yo need a score card just to know where she leans today.

Whatever the case, Ms. Clinton will move to right of center, in the debates, and try to be more Republican than Mr. Trump. Ronald Reagan must be rolling in his grave.

Of course, many Trump and Sanders supporters already know Ms. Clinton will say, and do anything, to get elected. So, she is going to trump Trump. That is, be something Paul Ryan,, Dick Cheney, GW Bush and Lindsey Graham will be proud of. She may be able to even impress Ted Cruz. That strategy may send Democrats away in drives.

Meanwhile, Mr. Trump will stay on point. That may actually help him.

As for those who were hoping for real change, and members of the 99%, Ms. Clinton will make Mr. Obama look like FDR in comparison. Of course, maybe voters will see through the Clinton charade and vote for someone else.
It was substantiated by a state judge.  That seems pretty direct to me. (para 5, this article)

Let's take this outside the context of Paterno and talk about the process. If someone says that they told you something and the court is not making any finding about the veracity of the allegation, what process, if any, do you have to disprove the allegation or request that  evidence be produced to assess whether there is any likelihood that it is truthful?

"pocket Bernie Sanders' economic proposals and make them her own"

You would believe her if she did?

BTW, Deb et al., I like the tips for novice/developing solvers that are included in the blog, but I'm not sure I see how the new format is more readable or standardized or whatever. I thought the old way was just fine...you always discussed the theme, maybe threw in an anecdote, then the constructor's notes, then a pithy sign-off and/or video of questionable intellectual-property provenance.

If it ain't broke, don't break it.
The article was merely reporting on how the family has kept this alive by their insistent denials, the latest being in response to the very newsworthy latest revelation.

"It hasn't been easy on the victims...." ?!?
Really?!? I can't even begin to fathom the tone deafness of such a comment.
For most sexual abuse victims their suffering is life long. You trivialize the impact of this aberrant behavior and it's dreadful consequences on the victims. I would suggest you reassess.

It is because they insist on making it public.  They insist on making their coping strategies as part of the public dialog.  Many, if not most, family have stories about themselves and their relations that wouldn't pass a truth test ('Uncle Bob wasn't really drunk when he crashed the car, it was just his medicine'), but they don't start a campaign trying to get others to believe the family myth.

An article mocking a family's support of their dead patriarch is as relevant, newsworthy, or important as the family's arguments in support of their now deceased patriarch.

What's the point of this? We know what happened. It hasn't been easy on the victims, the university or the family. We all understand that in abundance. I don't understand the compulsion to report on the Paterno family's coping strategies, however. Society has already passed its judgment. Nothing is left except journalistic scraps.

This whole exercise is unimportant and unnecessarily voyeuristic.

When I was growing up, I was told that participating in sports builds character, when I look at these guys, I sure don't believe it? Bobby Knight, Joe Paterno, Mike Tyson, the steroid baseball players, Lance Armstrong, Pete Rose?

I would not let one of these guys in my house! Crooks, thieves, cheaters, bullies. Not much character

Living in a college town where just about any behavior is justified in the name of winning, I find it tragic and completely expected that the family would behave in this way.  We saw our own personal flawed 'hero' trotted out last week by Trump and at the media seemed to forgot that Bobby Knight was fired by the Indiana University for his abusive (though not sexually) behavior toward just about everybody in his wake.  Yeah, how soon they forgot!  Trump talks about him as a "winner" as if nothing else matters.  But, then, in our culture does anything else matter?

As much as Joe Paterno was an enabler of Sandusky, so too was Penn State an enabler of Joe Paterno...as long as he won football games, they let him reign over the entire college...it took a lot of people, including a lot of fans to create this horrible situation.

Paterno's legacy as an enabler of a child-molester far outweighs anything he ever did on the football field. Paterno knew for at least a decade of Sandusky's pedophilia, and did nothing to prevent it. That alone was horrible on Paterno's part. If he knew of it 1976, even worse.
so why didn't the assistant coach do so?

That "kid" in the shower when questioned before Sandusky's trial stated that he was not molested.

You may want to know something about the case beyond what you read in the newspapers that fail to give the whole story or the testimony.

It´s easy to underestimate the impact of a years long strong top-down management system such as existed in the Paterno football program.   Decisions are made at the top.  After you have been in that type of system, you don´t even realize you are just ¨pushing it upstairs¨ because that is what is expected.  It takes years to change the group mental think of deferring to the top.  I worked in such a system and saw how difficult it was for people to take responsibility and challenge authority in any way.   I am sure the young man who reported it to Paterno has asked himself the same question you posed many times.
If you see an eleven year old in the shower with an adult you do everything in your power to protect that child.

As a parent, I really do not think it requires hindsight or for that matter, even judgment. Common sense and compassion for the kids would have moved most humans with some empathy to DO Something. Even to have Sandusky banned (?) from bringing these kids into the Penn State athletic facilities. All this lawyering, justifying and rationalization makes me ill. I cannot imagine what the victims and their families must be going through. For shame!

All that appeared to matter to Paterno was "his program" and the money and power he bought with its success.
The emphasis and FIRST concern of anyone in State College PA should be for the hundreds of children whose lives Sandusky, a pathological pedophile, destroyed-- alcoholism, drug abuse, mental health issues, depression, all of these are common to sexual abuse victims.
And the Penn State assistant coach who went to Paterno visibly upset after seeing Sandusky rape a boy in the shower?
The assistant should have tackled Sandusky and called the police ASAP. Forget telling the Paterno--he was too busy winning football games.
The family is grieving but what about the grief of the abuse victims? They'll grieve forever and forever feel betrayed as the "good men" of Penn State football stood by and did NOTHING to protect them.

"So the Hillary strategy has, in that sensed, worked. Many of us are left -- as is usual -- with no one to really support but no other place to go"

If you let that work, they'll just keep doing it. That is why they have kept doing it.

Reconsider a hand grenade in the system, meaning Trump. We are going to have a bad four years either way, but that way we'd get something better next time.
Whoop de do. If America needs to blow things up figuratively for once, and withdraw from the role of global menace for a few years, the world will just have to deal.

"No one really believed that the North American people would vote for such a buffoon."

This is what the Texans believed in 2000 about the American electorate and George W. Bush.

Dear Policarpa....
Since you're not in the US, you can be forgiven for not realizing that it's not the Donald's ring people are lining up to kiss, but the T-rump.

Señora Gail,
Your humor is perhaps the best antidote to the great pall that has come over the U.S. and the world after we woke up last Wednesday and earned that Donald Trump had become the presumptive Republican nominee. For many months, the primaries seemed entertaining. No one really believed that the North American people would vote for such a buffoon. But now it has happened and one can only make jokes, as you do here, about the establishment political class cueing up to compete to be Mr. Trump's vice president. We had seen "The Apprentice" on cable TV. Now politics is imitating reality TV and we will witness the spectacle of a stream of U.S. politicians waiting to kiss Mr. Trump's ring. From here, it's hard to discern whether it is the Republican Party which is committing suicide before our very eyes, or whether the US electorate has lost its collective mind and might even elect Trump as President. If it is the latter, don't expect the world to be supportive. We are repulsed and we will not play along. All of Latin America will rise up and say no to Trump's insulting wall and his bigoted rhetoric. Donald Trump, the ultimate Ugly American, will have recast the entire country into his own image. Let's hope that reason will somehow prevail and sanity restored in the US electorate.

yes, the author had a few nice moments, but having seen so much of the horribileness of this condition, both with friends and too many members of my own family, i feel sure that it would be more important not to go through with these dementias -- take your pick -- even though at the present time the state Supreme Court has said no Montana law forbids assisted end of life -- we have too many right-to-lifers who will take it into their own hands to harass any physician who tried to help -- we must choose to die with our own help before we are unable to.

how sick to deny us assistance.

If as claimed, Mr Paterno knew of Mr Sandusky's abusive action his legacy is not tarnished, but justifiably destroyed. There is no tradeoff worth the sort of  abusive behavior that ruins not only childhood, but adulthood as well. The best one can do is to forgive. There can be no absolution.

It's good that the family continues to fight, resulting in the truth and more dirt emerging on this false idol.  He will be remembered for one thing only - sheltering a child molester.  Anyone can coach football, but it takes a special person to shelter a child molester.

I just posted this. The Met's repertoire is DULL. It's more conservative than what one can hear in any major European city. It's more conservative than the San Francisco Opera or the Houston Grand Opera or even the tiny little Opera Theater of St. Louis. It's utterly, stultifyingly conservative. The same few Italian and German composers and operas, all from before 1950, over and over and over again.

Finally, next year, there'll be an opera by a woman, Kaija Saariaho, the first in many, many decades. Where are all the other modern and contemporary operas? Where are the operas that the great little Gotham Chamber Opera put on? Where are the operas that City Opera, when briefly under Mortier's tenure, planned to bring to town? Why is the only opera from the Modernist era Strauss's *Salome*?

Why are operas after 1950 so few, and the war horses so frequent? Is it the wealthy, aging funders? Is it fear? Will the Met too have to go out of business before things change?
Yeah, that is what 16 Republican candidates thought too.  Ask Rubio, Bush, and Cruz about that.

I am not a Republican or a Trump supporter but I would not count on Hillary controlling the debates...Trump is not a child and I have found that it's a mistake to treat grown men like children, even if they deserve it, it only makes matters worse. Hillary is not going to be prepared for Trump's level of crazy.

I agree with you on Hillary's debating skills, though on character and trust she has yet to win many of us. And there's a bit of verbal excess in your words "They crawled down into the sewer with him." The last I checked, only Marco Rubio stands guilty of hurling Trump-like filth into the Republican campaign.

Even Ted Cruz, loathsome though he was and remains for his ideas, came nowhere near Trump in this respect, though he did throw the justifiable epithet "pathological liar" at Trump . And despite their many other weaknesses, the rest of the Republican challengers, most notably John Kasich, Chris Christy, and Ben Carson, refused to dip their hands in slime.

Donald Trump has proven to be an unusual eel that no hands nor any net has caught yet. His opponents are impatient to destroy him, but my hope, not entirely unrealistic, is that he will self-destruct in the months to come . His tax returns should they become public; any sordid tales from his private life; and most of all an indictment for fraud in his for-profit " university" could individually or collectively undo him even before any debates.

If he barely survives all that due to court-room stalling , he will still have been softened up for a crushing blow from any Democratic or third-party ticket.

I really don't think Hilary Clinton needs the New York Times to tell her how to debate Donald Trump. First of all, Trump doesn't know how to debate. In order to debate, a person has to have something in their heads. He is the ultimate know nothing. All he can do is hurl insults and repeat slogans over and over again.

She knows how to handle spoiled children that throw tantrums when they don't get their way. She knows how to maintain dignity and act like a president. She also knows how to chop Trump into pieces if opens his big mouth at her.

Ten minutes into the first debate, she will expose him for the fool that he is. His competitors in the GOP contest were unable to do so because they were bigger fools than he is. They crawled down into the sewer with him. Didn't work.

Hillary is no ones fool. She can handle him.

You want to change Iran RIGHT NOW? How? War? Bombing without "war"? Troops on the ground (but not "war")? Those have been poor methods the past couple of decades -- bluntly, they've been disastrous.

The U.S. arms terrorists, too, by the way. The Saudi government, for one. (Sure, they pay cash. That's good for our economy.)
Fine.  Go ahead and file.  Or are you just another Leftist full of talk without any walk?
Don't "bring suit."  Vote. Vote them out of office at every opportunity when they don't do their job.

OR, Mark Hugh Miller, we could use grassroots synergy to blow up their phones, mailboxes, social media and every other communication method telling them to CONFIRM NOW. Let's start today. All the senators' phone numbers and websites are listed below.
http://www.democratichub.com/senate-list?t=ds

Maybe The New York Times could ask Mitch McConnell to sit down for a long interview, and explain why he and his Republican toadies won’t do their jobs. Oh, right - he says the American people must be allowed to choose. Or maybe that was Orrin Hatch, or perhaps John Cornyn.

Maybe the American people could sue the Senate obstructionists for breaching their sworn contract with us - their oath of office - which ends with the promise to "well and faithfully discharge the duties of the office on which I am about to enter: So help me God.”

How much more evidence do we need to bring suit?

That you turn these rhymes out on a dime every day is stunning, Larry, (especially when columnists get a week between their efforts) and that you were able to toss in "varlet", thereby educating some of the lesser of us on a word we did not know places you in the pantheon of the limerick gods.

I looked you up in Wikipedia and see that you are a youthful 97 years old and a biomedical engineer by trade. I want to be you when I grow up!

And Gail, thanks for providing Larry with such funny fodder.

Oh poor Christie had a sad when old Trumpette told his lad:

“Get on the plane and go home. It's over there . You go home.”

Chris Christie's the one in my book
Has a soulful and reverent look,
Behind Trump's rump stance
Almost in a trance,
He wants it by hook or by crook.

A reliable varlet and vassal
A handy chap if there's a hassle,
Sure to be loyal
To one who is royal
Of such chaps there isn't a passel.
